courseTitle: Principles of Molecular Pathology and Clinical Diagnostics
courseDescription: Basic concepts of molecular pathology & clinical diagnostics including nucleic acids, DNA replication, transcription, proteins, mutations and chromosome changes that underlie inherited and acquired/infectious disease, inheritance patterns and genetics as applied to oncology, cardiac disease and organ transplants.  Covers emerging molecular/cytologic/histologic methods (amplification, hybridization and micoarrays) to detect disease markers, monitor therapy and assess identity; pharmacogenomics and legal/ethical issues of genetic testing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of DNA replication and transcription
Expertise in proteins, mutations, and chromosome changes
Application of genetics to oncology, cardiac disease, and organ transplants
Use of molecular/cytologic/histologic methods to detect disease markers
Awareness of legal/ethical issues of genetic testing
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing legal and ethical issues in genetic testing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying genetic knowledge to diagnose and treat diseases

courseDescription: Course includes hands-on experience with or discussion of diagnostics instrumentation and assays using nucleic acid and protein extraction, gel electrophoresis, hybridization techniques, standard and real time polymerase chain reaction PCR), reverse transcription, DNA sequencing, autoradiography, flow cytometry, microarrays and proteomics-based methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Standard and real time polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data from PCR, DNA sequencing, and proteomics-based methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Maintaining accurate lab records and data

courseTitle: Advanced Clinical Applications of Molecular Diagnostics
courseDescription: Course will cover 1) new applications of standard molecular diagnostic techniques and 2) cutting edge technologies, instrumentation and technical advances, both as applied to clinical case studies. Emphasis will be on pharmacogenomics and disease processes including inherited conditions, cancer, hematopathology, infectious diseases, mental retardation and developmental delay. Innovative technologies covered include comparative genomic hybridization, pyrosequencing and bead based assays
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of cutting edge technologies and instrumentation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to apply technical knowledge to clinical case studies
Ability to communicate complex disease processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills to understand and interpret clinical case studies
Problem-solving skills to identify and analyze disease processes
Ability to use innovative technologies for problem-solving

courseDescription: Emphasis of this course will be on primer design for PCR, advanced real time PCR, cycle sequencing, capillary electrophoresis (CE) as applied to DNA sequencing, analysis of SNPS (single nucleotide polymorphisms), microsatellite instability, microarray technology and detection of methicillin-resistant bacteria. An optional three-week supervised rotation in a hospital-based molecular diagnostic laboratory or a molecular research laboratory.

Laboratory rotation with a pre-designated faculty member in which the student obtains hands-on experience. Designed for graduate students to sample different types of research models, techniques, and subject matter without the commitment of dissertation level involvement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of laboratory tools and equipment

courseTitle: Genomic Databases: Content, Curation, and Application to Biomedical Research
courseDescription: This course combines a didactic survey of topics important for understanding the origin, curation, advantages, and limitations of a variety of key genomic resources with hands-on training in the proper use of widely accessed public genome resources and common bioinformatic tools.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proper use of public genome resources
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the advantages and limitations of genomic resources
Didactic survey of key genomic topics

courseDescription: Course goals are a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in chromosome function and how aberrations in these processes contribute to human disease. Topics include DNA repair and recombination; centromere and telomere dynamics, maintenance, and function;  chromosome replication and segregation; control of cell division; dynamics of chromatin structure and function; epigenetics and gene expression; and long-range chromatin interactions and genome function.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of DNA repair and recombination
Knowledge in centromere and telomere dynamics, maintenance, and function
Comprehension of chromosome replication and segregation
Knowledge of chromatin structure and function dynamics
Understanding of epigenetics and gene expression
Comprehension of long-range chromatin interactions and genome function
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex biological processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing chromosomal abnormalities and their impact on human disease

courseDescription: Topics to be covered include history of stem cell biology, molecular definitions for stem cell identification, methods for stem cell isolations including: adult and embryonic, current technologies for induced pluripotent stem cell reprogramming, stem cells in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, and current and future stem cell applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of molecular definitions for stem cell identification
Proficiency in stem cell isolation methods
Familiarity with current technologies for induced pluripotent stem cell reprogramming
Understanding of stem cells in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex biological concepts
Ability to present findings on stem cell applications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of stem cell isolation techniques
Evaluation of current and future stem cell applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research on stem cell applications
Leading discussions on stem cell biology and therapy

courseDescription: Topics to be covered include history of tissue engineering, development and morphogenesis, tissue structure, cells, scaffolds, regulators, and creating and evaluating a tissue engineering construct. Focus is on biomedical tissue engineering concepts as applied to creating human tissues in the laboratory for surgical repair of injured and diseased tissues and organs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to work with scaffolds in tissue engineering
Understanding of regulators in tissue engineering
Creating and evaluating a tissue engineering construct
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex biomedical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for surgical repair of injured and diseased tissues and organs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing a biomedical laboratory
Leading a research team in tissue engineering

courseTitle: Molecular Genetics, Gene Function and Genomics
courseDescription: The goals of this course are a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in molecular genetics and gene function and in-depth exploration of modern experimental analyses of these processes. Topics include DNA replication, repair, and recombination; transcription; epigenetic regulation of transcription; chromatin structure, histone modifications, transcription factors, and regulatory RNAs; long-range chromatin interactions and gene regulation; post-transcriptional gene regulation and translation; molecular biology based experimental analysis of gene function; and experimental genomic approaches to gene regulation and gene function.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of DNA replication, repair, and recombination
Understanding of epigenetic regulation of transcription
Knowledge of chromatin structure, histone modifications, transcription factors, and regulatory RNAs
Understanding of long-range chromatin interactions and gene regulation
Knowledge of post-transcriptional gene regulation and translation
Ability to conduct molecular biology based experimental analysis of gene function
Ability to use experimental genomic approaches to gene regulation and gene function
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex genetic concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting results of gene function experiments

courseDescription: Course will cover molecular aspects of cancer including DNA damage, tumor viruses, cell cycle regulation, oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes and their respective roles in cancer prevention/development, genes involved in promoting or inhibiting metastasis, angiogenesis, telomeres and telomerase, regulation of both apoptosis and autophagy in normal and cancer cells, cancer stem cells, and diagnostic screening assays for therapeutic responses or resistance in cancer patients.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of molecular aspects of cancer
Understanding of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes
Knowledge of genes involved in promoting or inhibiting metastasis
Understanding of regulation of both apoptosis and autophagy in normal and cancer cells
Understanding of diagnostic screening assays for therapeutic responses or resistance in cancer patients
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex biological concepts
Ability to discuss cancer biology findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret cancer biology data
Understanding of the implications of various aspects of cancer biology for prevention and treatment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to keep up-to-date with the latest research in cancer biology
Ability to organize and present cancer biology information in a clear, coherent manner

courseTitle: Molecular Basis of Health and Disease
courseDescription: Emphasis is on human genetic syndromes and disorders associated with dysregulation of key signal transduction pathways that control gene expression, cell growth and protein synthesis including the Ras/MAPK pathway, tuberous sclerosis complex-mammalian target of rapamycin, PI3-kinase and others. Diagnosis, screening and treatment will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of key signal transduction pathways
Comprehension of tuberous sclerosis complex-mammalian target of rapamycin
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of diagnosis, screening, and treatment methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of disorders associated with dysregulation of key signal transduction pathways
Analysis of cell growth and protein synthesis
